TITLE: As Offices Ease Covid Safety Measures, Workers Worry
SUMMARY: Using local guidelines, many companies are loosening Covid safety rules, leaving workers to navigate masking and social distancing on their own.

TITLE: Confusion and Chaos in Hong Kong as Leaders Fumble Virus Response
SUMMARY: Government officials have been unable to curb an outbreak that has surpassed one million infections, leading Beijing to step up its intervention in the semiautonomous territory.

TITLE: China’s Information Dark Age Could Be Russia’s Future
SUMMARY: Russia and China have the tendency to learn the worst from each other: tyrants, famines, purges and, now, internet censorship.

TITLE: Where State Farm Sees ‘a Lot of Fraud,’ Black Customers See Discrimination
SUMMARY: The giant insurer is facing lawsuits from customers, agents and former employees accusing it of racial discrimination.

TITLE: Amid War in Ukraine, I.E.A. Warns Nations of Global Energy Crisis
SUMMARY: The International Energy Agency said countries should encourage use of mass transit and car pooling, among other things. That could also help the climate crisis.

TITLE: D.C. Suit Accusing Amazon of Controlling Prices Is Thrown Out
SUMMARY: The attorney general for the District of Columbia said Amazon made merchants on its site sell at the lowest price they charged on the web, resulting in higher prices overall.

TITLE: How the War in Ukraine Could Slow the Sales of Electric Cars
SUMMARY: The price of nickel, an essential ingredient in most batteries, has soared because of fear that Russian supplies could be cut off.

TITLE: D.C. Suit Accusing Amazon of Controlling Prices Is Thrown Out
SUMMARY: The attorney general for the District of Columbia said Amazon made merchants on its site sell at the lowest price they charged on the web, resulting in higher prices overall.

TITLE: Credit Companies Will Remove Stains From Repaid Medical Debts
SUMMARY: Debts that are paid off after they go to collections will be removed, instead of staying on a credit reports for up to seven years, Equifax, Experian and TransUnion announced.

TITLE: Av Westin, Newsman Behind ABC’s ‘20/20,’ Dies at 92
SUMMARY: After nearly 20 years at CBS News, he went to a rival network and helped turn its answer to “60 Minutes” into a frequent Emmy Award winner.

TITLE: Stocks notch their best week since November 2020.
SUMMARY: Some of the pressures that had combined to sour once-ebullient markets seemed to be easing.

TITLE: U.S. warns servicing or refueling some Russian-owned planes may violate trade restrictions.
SUMMARY: Export controls introduced in late February prohibit exporting aircraft that were made in the U.S. or use some U.S. parts to Russia, effectively grounding some international flights, the Commerce Department said.

TITLE: P & O Ferries Lays Off 800 U.K. Workers With No Notice
SUMMARY: The abrupt terminations caused widespread service cancellations and drew immediate backlash from government officials and unions.

TITLE: How Long Should It Take to Grieve? Psychiatry Has Come Up With an Answer.
SUMMARY: The latest edition of the DSM-5, sometimes known as “psychiatry’s bible,” includes a controversial new diagnosis: prolonged grief disorder.

TITLE: Russia’s Central Bank Projects Economic Decline
SUMMARY: Inflation and “large-scale structural transformation” are ahead, as the bank held interest rates at 20 percent.

TITLE: Jeanette Wagner, Who Globalized the Estée Lauder Brand, Dies at 92
SUMMARY: Meticulous in building relationships, she helped open new markets for the cosmetics company, notably in the Soviet Union, as head of its international operations.

TITLE: Colleges Can Avoid Shutting the Door on Financial Aid Knowledge
SUMMARY: We review Whitman College’s financial aid guarantee and Muhlenberg College’s refreshing explainer.

TITLE: Bringing Personal Finance to the Classroom for Generation Z
SUMMARY: Twenty-three states require high schoolers to take the subject, and more could join them in an effort to boost the next generation’s financial literacy.

TITLE: Ukraine Energy Company C.E.O. Tries to Keep Lights On During War
SUMMARY: DTEK, a prominent Ukrainian power company, arranges for soldiers to escort its emergency repair crews to reach damaged transmission lines.

TITLE: The Nickel Markets Are a Mess
SUMMARY: The chaos in trading of the metal could have broad implications.

TITLE: What to Do in Tampa, Florida
SUMMARY: From a Buddhist temple reached by boat to a storied hotel and a speakeasy bar: a cheat sheet on what to do in this Gulf Coast city, which has found new fans during the pandemic.

TITLE: BNY Mellon Says Russian Sanctions May Cost It $200 Million
SUMMARY: BNY Mellon has ceased new business in Russia and has “suspended investment management purchases of Russian securities,” it said.

TITLE: USAA Is Fined $140 Million for Bad Money Laundering Controls
SUMMARY: Regulators say the bank, which mainly serves U.S. military members, failed to keep track of its customers’ suspicious activities despite repeated warnings that it needed to improve.

TITLE: 35 companies sign on to produce generic versions of Pfizer’s Covid pill.
Uber, Lyft Drivers Struggle With High Gas Prices
SUMMARY: Some drivers say they find it hard to justify spending hours on the road for Uber or Lyft as fuel costs continue to tick upward.

TITLE: What a Federal Reserve Rate Increase Means for You
SUMMARY: Rates on credit cards, savings accounts and different kinds of loans move when the Fed changes its benchmark rate. Here’s what you need to know.

TITLE: Koch Industries Will Continue to Operate Factories in Russia
SUMMARY: Koch employs about 600 people in Russia through a unit that makes up a small part of its overall business.

TITLE: Citigroup Will Pay Travel Costs for Employee Abortions in Response to Texas Law
SUMMARY: Citigroup is the first major U.S. bank to announce a policy change in response to the legislation, which bans abortions after six weeks of pregnancy.

TITLE: House Votes to Suspend Normal Trade Relations With Russia
SUMMARY: The bill, which still needs Senate approval, is the latest in a series of measures that lawmakers have passed to support Ukraine and punish Russia for its invasion.

TITLE: NLRB Sues Amazon Over Labor Practices at a Staten Island Facility
SUMMARY: The labor agency wants a federal judge to order changes there in the case of a fired worker before a union election starts next week.

TITLE: Mortgage Rates Hit 4 Percent for First Time in 3 Years
SUMMARY: The average rate on 30-year fixed mortgages dropped as low as 2.65 percent in January 2021.

TITLE: Four Financial Tips for Buying a Second Home
SUMMARY: Second homes are becoming more expensive, and house hunters should examine interest rates, upfront fees, maintenance charges and taxes when calculating the cost.

TITLE: Bank of England Raises Rates for Third Time to Fight Inflation
SUMMARY: The bank on Thursday lifted its key interest rate to 0.75 percent, the third consecutive increase.

TITLE: Will Inflation Fix Itself?
SUMMARY: That appears to be what the Federal Reserve is counting on.

TITLE: Russia appears to have avoided default as it makes a $117 million bond payment.
SUMMARY: Sanctions have isolated the country financially, driven down the value of the ruble and cut off Moscow’s access to about half its foreign currency reserves.

TITLE: Amid Invasion of Ukraine, I.R.S. Aims to Police Oligarch Sanctions
SUMMARY: It wants to add agents to a 3,000-person investigations unit to help crack down on attempts by Russian oligarchs to evade sanctions.

TITLE: For Car Designers, E.V.s Offer a Blank Canvas
SUMMARY: Frunks are just the start — think Cybertruck, not Focus.

TITLE: Some Transgender People Used Remote Work to Make a Change
SUMMARY: After transitioning in private, they are preparing to return to the workplace at a time when gender identity itself is a politically divisive issue.

TITLE: Federal Reserve Walks a Tightrope Between Inflation and Recession
SUMMARY: American consumers already have high inflation. Because of the oil price shock and Russia’s war, the odds of a recession have increased, too.

TITLE: After Tragedy, a Female Construction Worker Builds Homes
SUMMARY: Female construction workers are still a rarity, but they are on the rise. After personal losses and three bouts of Covid-19, Deyonna Hancock is finding a new start in the industry.

TITLE: Chris Cuomo Seeks $125 Million From CNN
SUMMARY: Mr. Cuomo’s lawyers claim the money is owed to him for wrongful termination.

TITLE: Joe Buck and Troy Aikman to Host ‘Monday Night Football’
SUMMARY: Their multiyear deals will make the duo, who have called games together for 20 N.F.L. seasons, among the highest-paid sports broadcasters.

TITLE: Annie Flanders, Founder of Details Magazine, Dies at 82
SUMMARY: Her idiosyncratic and fiercely independent magazine chronicled Downtown Manhattan in the 1980s, a combustible mix of art, music and fashion.

TITLE: W.H.O. Delays Assessing Russia’s Sputnik Vaccine Over Ukraine War
SUMMARY: An official with the World Health Organization said “the assessment, along with inspections, have been affected.”

TITLE: Volkswagen Eyes U.S. Electric Vehicle Market as Ukraine War Disrupts Production
SUMMARY: Focusing on electric vehicles, Volkswagen aims for growth in North America, though it could face tough competition.

TITLE: Justin Smith, Former Bloomberg C.E.O., Offers New Details on Media Start-up
SUMMARY: The former Bloomberg Media C.E.O. offered new details on the venture he is starting with the journalist Ben Smith.

TITLE: Treasury Shifts Cash Among States as Pandemic Housing Aid Dries Up
SUMMARY: The Biden administration pulled back the aid from states and counties with unspent funds and diverted it to four states pressing for more: California, New York, New Jersey and Illinois.

TITLE: Exports to Russia Blocked by U.S. and Its Allies
SUMMARY: To try to halt the war in Ukraine, the U.S. and its allies have imposed the most sweeping export controls seen in decades on Russia. Now they have to enforce them.

TITLE: Mercedes Opens Alabama Battery Plant, Part of a Southern Wave
SUMMARY: The German automaker, which has made cars in the state for decades, has invested $1 billion in a factory to supply the power for electric vehicles.

TITLE: Retail sales rose in February, but inflation is starting to take its toll on spending.
SUMMARY: Sales rose 0.3 percent from January, a sharp slowdown in growth. Spending at electronics, appliance, furniture, health and personal care stores was lower.

TITLE: Starbucks C.E.O. Retires, and Howard Schultz Steps In as Interim
SUMMARY: Kevin Johnson, who was named chief executive in 2017, will leave his post on April 4.

TITLE: Russian Sanctions Could Create ‘Supply Crisis’ as Oil Output Falls
SUMMARY: The International Energy Agency said the global economy could be whipsawed by cuts in oil supplies and a sharp drop in demand.

TITLE: Markets Worry About a Russian Debt Default
SUMMARY: Russian debt faces an uncertain future.

TITLE: Warehouses Transform N.Y.C. Neighborhoods as E-Commerce Booms
SUMMARY: The region is home to the largest concentration of online shoppers in the country. The facilities, key to delivering packages on time, are reshaping neighborhoods.

TITLE: Why the Fed Raised Interest Rates
SUMMARY: The central bank wants a strong economy, but sustainability is the name of the game: A little pain today could mean less pain tomorrow.

TITLE: Genshin Impact, Smash Hit From China, Beats Japan at Its Own Game
SUMMARY: Genshin Impact, a nearly picture-perfect reproduction of Japanese fantasy role-playing games, has raked in billions of dollars and sent shock waves through the world’s aging video game superpower.

TITLE: David McCormick Faces Scrutiny Over Teacher Pension Investments
SUMMARY: David McCormick, a Republican Senate candidate in Pennsylvania, came under attack from his chief rival, Dr. Mehmet Oz, over the underperformance of investments for the state’s teachers.
